categories.title: ElizaOS Development Updates and Community Discussions - December 14-15, 2025

content.text: Shaw provided updates on ElizaOS Cloud development, describing it as focused on quickly building agents, apps, n8n workflows, and MCP/A2A services. The platform features a create-publish-monetize-promote loop with integrated SEO, advertising network, and social publishing capabilities. Shaw mentioned that getting X (Twitter) access back is looking very likely. Community members expressed excitement about Cloud and suggested using the partners channel as an Eliza-Alpha preview space for strategic people to test and broadcast new developments.

A security incident was reported regarding the ElizaOS migration site being potentially hacked or hijacked, with users reporting stolen funds. The site was prompting users to connect wallets and requesting approval for valuable tokens. Moderators and admins were alerted and confirmed they were investigating the issue. One user reported being robbed due to this exploit.

Significant discussion occurred around the AI16Z to ElizaOS token migration, particularly affecting Korean users on Bithumb exchange. Korean community members expressed frustration about delays and lack of communication regarding migration progress. Helper moderators clarified that migration for tokens held on centralized exchanges is the exchange's responsibility, not the foundation's. Users were directed to contact Bithumb support regarding suspended deposits and trading issues. Some users speculated that AI16Z might perform better than ElizaOS given the price movements.

Development discussions included issues with Twitter replies causing database failures due to foreign key constraints, with suggestions to try the latest codebase containing SQL fixes. A community member shared OpenCode, an open source coding agent by SST, suggesting ElizaOS needs similar connectors. For hosting recommendations, Hetzner and OVH were suggested as preferred VPS options. One developer successfully set up NFL trade data tracking with Neon database and received assistance via voice chat.

Core developers established new PR submission rules requiring screenshots or 1-2 minute videos demonstrating feature work to improve reviews and ensure functionality. The rule emphasizes that PRs must be tested in production, not just pass AI reviews or build successfully. Discord voice channel permissions were updated to make dev-voice public while keeping private-dev-voice restricted to core developers and master admins.

A product beta for myguo AI was shared, described as AI-native portfolio intelligence for onchain users. The post was later flagged as a scam alert by community members. Multiple scammer accounts were identified and banned throughout the discussion period.

On December 15, 2025, ElizaOS made significant progress across its plugin ecosystem and core repository. The development focused on three main areas: architectural improvements to plugins, critical bug fixes for system stability, and a comprehensive set of UI/UX enhancement proposals.

Completed Work: The core eliza repository achieved important stability improvements. The team fixed an API signature mismatch in CLI e2e-tests that was causing command failures, corrected a unit test mock function name for character retrieval testing, and implemented smooth migration from pre-1.6.5 camelCase to 1.6.5+ schema conventions within the SQL plugin. This migration work included optimized Row-Level Security (RLS) handling and comprehensive test coverage.

Work in Progress: Two major plugin refactoring efforts are underway. The plugin-discord repository has an open pull request for refactoring message handling, while the plugin-telegram repository is working on a codebase refactor that implements a unified messaging API with enhanced ElizaOS integration support.

New Issues - Dashboard and Onboarding: Multiple issues were opened to improve the user experience. Proposals include redesigning the dashboard to prioritize agent and app creation with monetization opportunities, implementing guided onboarding overlays for new users, adding a chat interface to the landing page for goal-oriented user routing, and elevating Apps to a first-class product section. Post-agent-creation guidance for deployment was also proposed.

New Issues - Agent Management and UI Improvements: Several enhancements were proposed for agent creation and management workflows. These include adding tooltips for Style and Personality tabs, placeholder text for empty input fields, allowing text input while agents process, enabling avatar creation and deployment via chat commands, renaming Save to Deploy and Build to Edit for existing agents, and adding three-dot menus to agent cards for quick edit and delete options.

New Issues - Plugin and File Management: Additional UI improvements were proposed for plugin selection and file handling. These include better visual feedback for plugin selection with toggle behavior, increased visibility of the Choose Files button, removal of the two-step upload process, renaming the Knowledge section to Files, replacing RAG terminology with plain language, and using Services instead of MCP in the UI.

New Issues - Bug Fixes and Feature Proposals: The team identified several bugs and feature requests, including an avatar mismatch between edit view and sidebar, chat suggestions in edit mode incorrectly triggering agent responses, and a proposal for an AI Agent Payment Implementation Guide using Circle and Coinbase APIs.
